Introduction:
The European Union (EU) plays a significant role in shaping the health policies of its member states. The EU has been actively working to improve the health of its citizens through various initiatives such as the European Health Strategy, the EU Health Program, and the EU Health Insurance Card. However, there is growing debate about whether the EU should take on a more active role in health policy, particularly in areas such as public health and healthcare financing.

Public health is a shared responsibility among the EU member states, but the current state of healthcare in the EU is diverse, with significant differences in the quality of healthcare and access to healthcare services among member states. This variation in healthcare systems poses a challenge for the EU in addressing public health issues such as infectious diseases, chronic diseases, and health inequalities. The EU has to deal with the increasing burden of healthcare costs on member states as well as the sustainability of healthcare financing systems.

The EU has been working to improve the health of its citizens by fostering cooperation and coordination among member states, supporting the development of common policies and strategies, and providing funding and technical assistance. However, there is a need to take a more active role in health policy, particularly in areas such as public health and healthcare financing. By doing so, the EU would be able to address the diverse healthcare systems of member states, public health issues, and healthcare financing challenges.

In this policy brief, we will explore the problem of the current state of healthcare in the EU, the potential policy options that the EU could adopt to play a greater role in health policy, and the recommended policy option. We will also discuss the implementation of the recommended policy option and the potential impact of the EU playing a greater role in health policy.

This policy brief is intended for policymakers, healthcare professionals, and interested citizens. It aims to provide an overview of the current state of healthcare in the EU, the potential policy options, and the recommended policy option. It also aims to provide a detailed analysis of the potential impact of the EU playing a greater role in health policy.
